div.p: Greetings. I received the gift sent to my wife, most esteemed man in every way, and I am amazed at the benevolence of the most gracious council, since there are no benefits from me that would cause them to love me so much. However, I will try in every way to conduct myself so that they will never regret their love and support for me. I also ask you to thank the most honorable council on my behalf. In the meantime, be assured that I have not received a single hair, whoever besides you and yours might have offered it. For I have not been accustomed to it, indeed I have consistently rejected honorary gifts offered by cities and most distinguished men, and I will not accept any, God willing, as long as I live. The Archbishop of Canterbury and several leading men of England offered, Bern and Augsburg offered, others offered; I never accepted even a penny from anyone. There are many and very just reasons why I act this way. - In the months of January and February, I wrote twenty sermons, a copy of which I send here. I pray that you kindly accept this small gift. God willing, I will prepare four more Decades, in which I will address other most necessary commonplaces of evangelical theology.

There are no copies of Calvin's response here; what I sent you, I received from Calvin himself. On the twelfth of this month, a great synod will be held in Bern. All the ministers of the churches of the Bernese dominion have been called there; after eight days, the French or Savoyard ministers will also appear. Therefore, Musculus remains in Bern to attend the synods.

I return to you the shared papers on the English parricide, written from Antwerp, and I give you great thanks. Friends from England weave almost the same story in the same words; but I have nothing more than yours. May the Lord turn everything to the glory of His name. I await what else friends from Antwerp will write; for you promise to share them with us.
May the Lord grant you wisdom and the ability to resolve the controversial issue among the Swiss. Farewell. The lords consuls and fellow brothers greet you.
Your Bullinger. Return all enclosed letters to the most distinguished man, Mr. D. D.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. D. D. Joachim Vadian, his most esteemed lord. St. Gallen.
